title: Beauty therapist evicted over worst case of hoarding firefighters had ever seen
text:

A retired beauty therapist has been evicted after firefighters discovered "the worst hoarding they have ever seen" in her home.

Susan Ralphs, 70, now claims she and her three cats have nowhere to live after her housing association, Adra, gave her the boot.

But a court heard the pensioner left her property in serious disrepair.

"I am a bit of a hoarder, and the fire brigade officers who have been here say it's the worst hoarding they have ever seen and that it's a fire risk," Ms Ralphs told North Wales Live today.

"They are evicting me just when I started to get my health back and I was going to sort the house out.

"I was given eight weeks to do so by Adra, and I was going to do it, but sadly my health failed.

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

"When they evict me on Monday, I will have nowhere else to go, and all I want is to sit in my beloved home with my cats and see the sun and stars from my garden."

A two-day hearing at Caernarfon Crown Court last month was told the pensioner cannot appeal against Adra's decision.

Ms Ralphs, who had been living in the home in Blaenau Ffestiniog, north Wales for four years, claims her hoarding problem started as she suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder and had what she describes as a "tough upbringing".

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

"Mostly it's because I moved here from a place that had five bedrooms, so I have lots of bags of clothes, bedding and curtains, but I am very hygienic," she added.

"I have no idea what is going to happen to my lovely possessions after Monday," she said.

"I'm worried they are going to end up in a skip.

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

"I just wish someone could help me not get evicted, as I'm a good and kind person who has gone out of my way to help others. This is all so traumatic for me."

A spokesman for Adra said: "Our priority is always to support and sustain tenancies and we work with partner agencies to try and prevent homelessness.

"We only take legal action as a last resort. In this case, the court decided that the granting of possession was reasonable and proportionate."
description: Susan Ralphs is being evicted by housing association Adra from her property in north Wales - but she insists she is "very hygienic"
